instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I have found a short on 3.42 and have removed L6995 it seem it coming from the <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> side. Should I remove capacitor one by one until I find it? Also what is the best method in keeping the caps in arrangement so they don?t get mixed up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<CHIP>U6900</CHIP> is not connected on 3V42 power rail, but <CHIP>U6901</CHIP>.
Of course there are many other chips and caps.
You should post exact ohm value reading.

And start checking the caps near the BIL connector; under the black sponge, as common fail...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Ok I will check that area. I will post the some ohm values later thank you.
